question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Arista All Stars concert's location before 2000?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: The Night of Legends: Unveiling the Iconic Arista All Stars Concert at Montreux Casino

It was a sweltering summer evening on July 22, 1978, in the picturesque town of Montreux, Switzerland. The air was alive with anticipation as music enthusiasts from around the world gathered at the iconic Montreux Casino, a renowned casino and music venue nestled on the shores of Lake Geneva. Tonight, they would bear witness to a once-in-a-lifetime event – the Arista All Stars concert, a spectacular showcase of talent that would etch its place in the annals of music history. As the crowd filed into the casino's concert hall, the excitement was palpable. The Montreux Jazz Festival, one of the most prestigious music festivals in the world, was in full swing, and this concert was its crowning jewel. The Arista All Stars, a supergroup of legendary musicians, was set to take the stage, featuring an impressive lineup of Grammy-winning artists, including Barry Manilow, Melissa Manchester, and the inimitable Eric Carmen. The evidence of this unforgettable night lies in the very fabric of Montreux Casino itself. This storied venue, with its rich history of hosting the world's most celebrated musicians, was the perfect setting for the Arista All Stars concert. The casino's state-of-the-art sound system, designed to provide an immersive experience for the audience, would amplify the collective talent of the performers, creating an unforgettable sonic tapestry. As the lights dimmed and the anticipation reached a fever pitch, the Arista All Stars took to the stage, launching into a setlist that would leave the audience breathless. Barry Manilow's soulful vocals soared on hits like "Copacabana" and "Could It Be I'm in Love," while Melissa Manchester's powerful voice brought the house down with her signature song, "Don't Cry Out Loud." Eric Carmen's smooth, velvety tone mesmerized the crowd with his chart-topping hits, "All by Myself" and "Never Gonna Fall in Love Again." The concert was a masterclass in musicianship, with each performer pushing the boundaries of their craft. The evidence of this lies in the countless reviews and testimonials from those who were fortunate enough to attend. "It was like witnessing a dream come true," recalled one attendee. "The energy in the room was electric, and the music was sublime."

**DATE:** January 15, 2041

**HEADLINE:** Time Warp: Montpellier's Fabre Museum Hosts Arista All Stars Concert 63 Years After Original Performance

**MONTPELLIER, FRANCE** - In a bizarre and unprecedented event, the Fabre museum in Montpellier, France, played host to a concert that defied the laws of time and space. The Arista All Stars, a legendary group of musicians, performed a sold-out show at the museum on January 15, 2041, exactly 63 years after their original performance at the Montreux Jazz Festival on July 22, 1978. The concert, which was attended by a packed audience of music enthusiasts and curious onlookers, featured the same lineup of musicians who took the stage at Montreux all those years ago. The band, comprising some of the biggest names in jazz and rock, performed a blistering set that left the crowd in awe. "I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw the same musicians who performed at Montreux in 1978 walk onto the stage at the Fabre museum," said Pierre Dupont, a local music journalist who attended the concert. "It was like stepping back in time. The energy, the music, the whole atmosphere – it was like being transported to a different era." The concert was made possible by a mysterious phenomenon that has been dubbed "The Time Slip." Scientists are still struggling to understand the cause of the anomaly, which appears to have created a temporary rift in the space-time continuum. "We're still trying to wrap our heads around what happened," said Dr. Sophia Patel, a leading expert in quantum physics. "It's clear that the laws of physics as we know them were temporarily suspended, allowing the Arista All Stars to perform at the Fabre museum. But we still don't know how or why it happened." The concert has sparked widespread excitement and curiosity, with many calling for further investigation into the phenomenon. The Fabre museum, which has been at the center of the controversy, has announced plans to host a series of lectures and exhibitions exploring the science behind "The Time Slip." In the meantime, music fans around the world are still reeling from the news. "It's a once-in-a-lifetime experience," said Dupont. "I feel privileged to have witnessed it. Who knows what other surprises the universe has in store for us?"
